awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Faculty as Change Agents: Transforming Geoscience Education in Two-year Colleges
awd_abstract_narration:
Two-year colleges (2YCs) play crucial roles in meeting the Nation's geoscience and STEM workforce needs and in increasing public scientific literacy. Nationally, 2YCs enroll over 45% of all U.S. undergraduates and serve a large number of women, minority, and first-generation college students. The 2YC teaching environment is one of the most challenging as community colleges are primarily open-access institutions that serve an extremely diverse student body; teaching loads are heavy; there is an increasing use of adjunct faculty; and support is limited for participation in faculty professional development activities. The latter issue is particularly crucial since such activities are widely recognized as the source for many innovative teaching methods shown to be critically important for improving student learning. This faculty professional development project will build a national network of self-sustaining local communities of 2YC geoscience faculty and administrators who use evidence-based strategies to improve all students' academic success and facilitate professional pathways into the STEM workforce. A program of interconnected and mutually supportive research and evaluation that is fully integrated in the project will advance knowledge and understanding of the effectiveness of a professional development model for full-time and adjunct geoscience and STEM faculty in 2YCs. 

The project goals are to 1) implement high-impact evidence-based instructional and co-curricular practices that support the academic success of all students and promote professional pathways into geoscience; 2) build a sustainable national network of 2YC leaders who catalyze change at multiple levels from their courses to institutions in their local regions and within the community of practice; and 3) investigate models of professional development for full-time and adjunct 2YC geoscience faculty that promote the cycle of innovation, where faculty learn from the research of others, make changes in their own practice, and share what they have learned with the education community. The project's professional development program will prepare two cohorts of 2YC geoscience faculty teams to implement evidence-based instructional and co-curricular practices at their institutions. The first cohort includes twenty-four (24) full-time and adjunct faculty from seventeen (17) institutions in ten regions in the United States. National workshops, virtual professional development opportunities (e.g., journal clubs, webinars, implementation and discussion groups), and on-line resources will support faculty in implementing changes on their campus. Inclusion of administrators in the project will provide support for systemic change at each institution. The faculty teams will expand the reach of the project by engaging additional two-year and four-year institutions in their regions using a combination of workshops and follow-on activities. Virtual professional development opportunities will serve as a mechanism for increasing the reach of the project and on-line resources will provide persistent resources for the full geoscience and broader STEM communities. The project team anticipates that six-hundred (600) full-time and adjunct 2YC faculty and fifty (50) four-year college and university faculty will be engaged in professional development activities over the course of the project and that the project will impact an estimated 250,000 2YC students enrolled in geoscience courses.

por.por_cntn:
Two-year colleges (2YCs) play crucial roles in meeting the nation's geoscience and STEM workforce needs and in increasing public scientific literacy. Supporting and Advancing Geoscience Education in Two-Year Colleges: Faculty as Change Agents (SAGE 2YC) was a professional development program for 2YC geoscience faculty that built a national network of 2YC geoscience and other STEM faculty to implement evidence-based strategies for improving students' academic success, broadening participation in STEM, and facilitating students? professional pathways into the STEM workforce. These faculty catalyzed changes at multiple levels in their courses and departments, on their campuses and in their regions, and in their disciplines.

The SAGE 2YC program engaged three cohorts of faculty teams (overall 80 faculty, including adjuncts, from 38 institutions). They implemented evidence-based instructional practices, designed an action plan to strengthen their program using course-level data, and led professional development activities for faculty in their institution or region. The faculty teams were generally from the same institution; however, the length and modality of the professional development were different for each cohort. Cohort 1 teams participated in both face-to-face annual workshops and virtual activities for four years; Cohort 2 teams participated in two years of virtual activities and a final face-to-face workshop. Cohort 3 teams, which expanded participation beyond geoscience, participated in one year of virtual workshops and activities in 2020; some also participated in a Cohort 3 Leadership Extension. The Cohort 3 experience in this virtual environment gave them a head start to remote teaching during the pandemic. They expressed gratitude for this unanticipated aspect of the project and shared their new skills with their colleagues and in their teaching (Eddy et al., 2021)  

Several distinctive program elements contributed to SAGE 2YC success. Participants analyzed course-level data on student participation and success, then intentionally applied strategies to address equity gaps (Bragg et al., 2020; Ormand et al., 2021); the inclusion of administrators in the project provided support for systemic change at each institution; and virtual activities during the academic year (e.g., book clubs, journal clubs, and implementation groups) provided support for making changes in their practice (Ormand et al., 2021). Each Change Agent team led an annual workshop or other professional development activity in their region or for their campus, which both reinforced their learning about the workshop topic(s) and increased the reach of the SAGE 2YC programs (Macdonald et al., 2019). From 2016 to 2021, Change Agent teams led more than 90 in-person and virtual workshops and other activities, reaching at least 1200 people, 19% were adjunct faculty. Workshop topics included active learning strategies, metacognition, inclusive teaching practices, supporting student transfer to four-year institutions, and more.

An explicit focus on leadership development was a novel part of the program. Change Agents learned about leadership approaches and organizational change and put their knowledge and insights into practice in their action plans and workshops. Cohort 1 and 2 Change Agents who served as Peer Leaders for Cohort 3 programs gained additional leadership experience. Overall, SAGE 2YC built capacity for 2YC faculty to lead as mid-level leaders, either as grassroots leaders or to step into administrative positions (Iverson et al., 2020) and provided a stream of faculty willing to take on leadership roles in the National Association of Geoscience Teachers Geo2YC Division (Tvelia et al., 2021). Project-led workshops at professional meetings and the project website extended the reach of the project. Change Agents in the program were both learners and leaders, accelerating the diffusion of high-impact practices.

The program improved undergraduate teaching practices in the geosciences with a shift toward student-centered practices. The increased use of evidence-based teaching contributed to improved course completion rates and reduced equity gaps (Bragg et al., 2020). The Change Agents reported that their use of evidence-based practices increased their confidence in sharing what they learned with others and seeing themselves grow as faculty leaders (Bragg et al., 2020; Eddy & O?Connell, 2021). By the end of the project, the majority of Change Agents reported using various forms of data to improve their practices, attributing the SAGE 2YC project with inspiration for the changes they were making in their classrooms and institutions. The project also contributed to increased regional and professional engagement among geoscience educators. The program fostered a vibrant community of practice; with shared goals and the common context of teaching in a community college, they interacted regularly and improved their practice.  

SAGE 2YC Change Agents learned new ways to support student success; promote diversity, equity, and inclusion; facilitate students' career and transfer pathways; lead faculty professional development; and promote other change initiatives. They grew as leaders. When faculty members use an inquiry mindset regarding teaching and learning, actively analyze data to understand how change is happening for their students, they are well-positioned to change and work to improve student success.
